  29. This trimmer, while looking sophisticated in photos, is not really very useful. It does not cut at all other hair - all those hair all over your ears, all those almost invisible hair on your upper cheeks, etc. I had a trimmer for about 14 years until its motor burned out - it cut all those other hair and I also used it to cut hair in my arm pits and even my pubes. Plus another good thing about that old trimmer was that as it worked all hair fell off instead of depositing inside it. But this trimmer collects all hair inside its cutting cap that I have to remove and clean after every use. I cannot use it on arm pits and pubes also because those big hair would collect inside it and might damage it. I would say do not buy it - you probably need a multi-purpose trimmer like the one I had for 14 years.
  30. The best trimmer so far...all pros and no cons!
  31. This one really works, very fast it doesn't pull or hurt like others, had another one that was slow, didn't work well, it was a painful experiance, and the battery was dead all the time.
  32. I like this type of nose hair trimmer. I have used two other brands that were of the vibrator type and they were almost useless. I had owned a Panasonic years ago but lost it in my travels. This model has a rotary motor that is far more effective than the vibrator type. The case is also handy for traveling.

  37. This trimmer is something I've been looking for but was trepidatious to purchase for fear of the nose hair pulling that has happened in the past. Well, I'm happy to say, none of that is the case with this trimmer. No pulling, tearing or catching at all. It zips along at a rapid pace and cuts the hairs cleanly - for the most part. It cleaned out my nose and ear hairs very effectively with the exception that, sometimes, because of the way the end is designed, you have to go over the same hair a dozen times before they get clipped. Otherwise, it's great. I highly recommend it. In fact, it tickles my nose which makes me laugh. Now that's a nice benefit to having to trim unsightly hairs.
  38. This was a very good buy for me. It works really well. The thing on the bottom is sorta hard to take off but it does come off. That is where you have to put the battery. 4/5 Starrs from me.

  40. This is my first nose hair trimmer and I am really impressed with both comfort and results. I feel like a cave man for not having owned a device like this before. The unit cuts well and doesn't pull my hair; it cuts hair down to a stubble length as you work it around the nostril. Speaking of nostrils, mine feel glorious right now; I can't remember the last time my air flow felt so unimpeded. It easily cuts hair in many areas that are difficult and time consuming to reach with scissors. The vacuum sucks up most of the trimmings and the blade housing can be easily taken apart and cleaned. It runs on one AA battery (not included). What's not to like? With such solid performance, I can't understand any of the negative reviews... particularly considering how inexpensive this trimmer is. It does a great job for less than a Jackson (shipped).

  47. For the last three years I've been using the [[ASIN:B000W405SG Philips Norelco NT9110 Precision Nose and Ear Trimmer]]. I liked its versatility (the eyebrow comb in particular) and how it could reach in further than the rotary-style trimmer. However, it started to jam on a regular basis and eventually broke, so I bought the Panasonic ER430K as a replacement.<br /><br />First, that mirror cap. It seems Panasonic read the complaints of other reviewers that there were no instructions to remove the protective film. On mine, there was a big \\"Peel off\\" printed on this film. That said, the reflective cap didn't seem to be useful - I tried various angles and it didn't add any value for me. But that wasn't why I bought it.<br /><br />The trimmer itself works well, though as I note above it doesn't reach in quite as far as my old Norelco. I like that it is washable, though I'd think that using it in the shower would be self-defeating as the hairs would not stick out well, but perhaps I should try it some day. It is easy to disassemble and wash out.<br /><br />The vacuum is a nice touch - I have a Philips beard trimmer with a vacuum - and I could see the hair clippings on the filter screen. I never had an issue with nose hair clippings irritating my nose, but evidently some do and the ER430K seems to remove a good amount of the hair.<br /><br />Panasonic's instructions suggest that you can use this trimmer on eyebrows, mustaches, etc. I suppose you can, yes, but with no ability to control cut length I'm not sure why you would. That said, it works well at trimming stray hairs wherever they may be.<br /><br />A nice touch is the zippered carrying bag. It's also nice to know that the removable parts can be ordered separately should they break, wear out or get lost.
  48. I just totally changed my review of this. Initially it seemed to cut well, and I posted a response based on that. Well, there was a slight change in my viewpoint and now I have sent it to the landfill. The first problem was that although it did initially cut well, I have no idea how but it also cut something in my nose. Thinking I had hit it at the perfect angle at the perfect time, I blew it off as nothing to worry about. Then it happened again and again. At that point I was very conscious of how I used it. That was the first downfall. The next was what someone else had stated--- Panasonic is all about the vacuum portion of it--- with that, it doesn't do much for me and the other part of that is the cutters just simply didn't last. I have been using it over 18-months and I noticed that it makes a lot of noise and just doesn't cut correctly. With that, since my previous two were Wahl and they performed OK, I was on the lookout for something else that may work better. I even entertained the thought if a manual version, but I couldn't honestly seeing it work they way I wanted it to, plus it would take two hands at once--- maybe I'll try it someday, but not now.<br /><br />So what I went and tried was an Andis 13430. It looks like in more than one way like a Wahl--- maybe it is, maybe not. Either way, for under $10 I have used it a couple of times and it works much better than the Panasonic. No propensity to nick or cut. Also the resonant frequency that it naturally vibrates at makes my nose tickle less... maybe it is the Panasonic vacuum thing, but either way I sent the Panasonic packing and moved on. I do not expect these things to work perfect, but they should work to some extent. I would have thought more from Panasonic, but for this it is worth looking at something else.

When I would look in my nose after using this, there would always be a bunch of fairly long hairs in the corners and elsewhere. The cone design is horrible. The hairs have a hard time getting past it. Just look at it. It has a few slits around the side. My nosehairs are all supposed to slip past that? I thought i would give the slim clipper style a try.   59. Had used the smaller version of this trimmer for years and loved it, but then I dropped it onto the cutter head and dented it. It wouldn't rotate any more so I had to buy a new one. I thought I would splurge and get the \\"top of the line\\" model. That was a mistake. First, this vacuum model is huge. Not that it's a foot long or anything, but compared to the non-vacuum model it is ginormous. It doesn't fit the hand well and will take up additional room in my shaving kit when traveling. Oh, and the \\"mirror\\" on the top cap is a complete joke. Speaking of jokes, the vacuum feature... it's completely worthless. I do feel air pulling through my nose and (annoyingly) venting onto my hand/face, but my nostrils are just as full of trimmed bits of hair when I'm done as with the non-vacuum model. In the older model, I would take off the cap and there would be a good bit of hair in with the blade. On this \\"premium\\" vacuum model, I have yet to find any hair in the unit. There is a filter inside the cap, so either the trimmed bits are all staying in my nose, or else the particles are too tiny and are passing right through the mesh filter. I'd rather have them in the cap, thank you. Also, on the older, smaller model, a battery would last for months, sometimes 4-6 months when used 2-3 times per week. This vacuum model is eating batteries in 4-6 weeks. So, do yourself a favor and save a few bucks and get the simpler model [...] - you'll be glad you did!

  61. After doing extensive research, I decided to purchase this. Some important things to note: -It uses normal batteries. There's no recharger. -Build quality feels very cheap. It's entirely made out of plastic, with some small metal components. Don't drop it on the ground! -It's about the length of a toothbrush. Fits very easily into a suitcase, although if your nose hair is growing so fast you need to pack this thing for multiple uses, something's wrong with you. Now onto my personal experience. I've owned this thing for quite a while, but have only used it three times. I'm afraid to use it again, because the first time I stuck it in, it immediately induced an awful itchy feeling, causing me to want to blow my nose violently. My nose immediately started to secrete mucus from the irritation, and I noticed the mucus was bloody. I followed the directions exactly as said, and to this day don't know how it happened. This cut persisted for about a week, and my nose was sore to the touch for the duration. My subsequent uses have all induced an itch, though I didn't bleed from use those times. Beware!

  68. I just bought this facial hair trimmer by Panasonic for my husband via Amazon. I placed the order and it took about 5-6 days to reach us. I did a little research before buying a new unit. I have bought a good 2-3 of those trimmers they advertise on t.v. on infomercials, but they always seemed to die out early and we couldn't get a good battery replacement for them. We now have 2-3 dead trimmers sitting in his cupboard. So...I looked at the feedback of other Amazon reviewers and this unit seemed to get solid feedback. This unit is small and compact. It takes up little space in the cupboard and will be easy to take on trips and outings as well. It only needs 1 AA battery to run. A quick push to a button up turns it on, remove your thumb and it goes off. The little cutter on the tip is well protected and just causes a gentle tickling sensation when used on the edge of the ear or nose canal. We have not tried it on the eyebrows or sideburns yet, but expect no issues there. There is a built in vaccum that sucks in the debris so, it doesn't go all all over the place. The unit is quiet when it use. It comes in an attractive black/silver finish. A simple black nylon case comes with this unit for final storage. For the price, I think this is a great piece. As long as it works over the long haul, I think we got a nice trimmer that will stand the test of time. Buy it, I think you'll like it.

  93. People sometimes look at getting older in a completely negative light. I'm happy to say that there are many aspects of being in my mid-40s that are just fine. I am in great physical condition. I am old enough to say something in a meeting and have other people take me seriously, and yet young enough that the 20-somethings with whom I work can still consider me cool (or at least that's what I tell myself). But one thing they don't necessarily tell you about in the book of aging: hair tends to start sprouting from places you'd really never had to maintain in your younger years. Perhaps it is making up for the retreat from my skull.<br /><br />In any case, I never previously had a need for such a device as a nose hair trimmer. Well, that's not true; I've needed one for at least four years. But perhaps being in a state of denial, I never purchased a dedicated tool for said need. Instead, I grimaced at the hair that extended from my nostrils, and hacked away at them with a small pair of scissors. As I would attempt this, I would get a macabre daydream of slipping and falling, jamming said scissors into my brain, and dying in an ignobious manner. Plus, it never really worked very well... and was especially unnerving when I'd try the same thing with the hair that began emerging from my ears.<br /><br />Enter the Panasonic ER430K. Since this was my first purchase of a grooming device such as this, I looked at reviews and compared feature sets and all that stuff that a good consumer is supposed to do. What I found was that a) people liked the 430K and b) there wasn't that huge of a price difference between this top-of-the-line Panasonic model and their lesser offerings. Plus, I was already buying holiday gifts for other people at the time, so I might as well bite the bullet and get this device at a good price and with the free shipping that came along with my sizable Amazon order.<br /><br />It was about as simple as possible to set up. Unscrew the battery compartment, pop in a AA battery, and there you are. The next part -- using the device -- seemed self-explanatory. You turn on the switch, and stick it into your nose. Since it has a built-in vacuum, you aren't facing the somewhat disgusting task of cleaning your discarded nose hair clippings from your nose and the front of your shirt after using it. I will say, for those of you with little experience in these matters: shoving a buzzing razor into your nose is an odd experience at best, and you should be prepared for it to tickle in a way that you probably haven't felt before. The same goes for the first time you use it in your ears.<br /><br />That having been said, it seems to be tremendously effective. I am happy to say that in looking in the mirror after my first use, both my nose and ears were quickly devoid of unwanted hair. And that's why we get devices like this one, isn't it? Look, I'm fine being in my mid-40s. I'm fine with my greying beard, and the bit of wobble around my waistline. But the nose and ear hair had to go. The Panasonic ER430K did everything I wanted it to, was easy to use, and didn't cost a lot. What more can I ask for?

With out the extra blades, and the fact that the two rotating blades that it does have sit pretty far down into the device - it seems as though this unit requires a lot of manual manipulation once inside your nose \\"in and out then turn the unit, in and out then turn again\\". Don't know if this is normal because this is my first unit. The vacuum feature is definitely a plus. Beware when you are rinsing out the head of nose hair clippings. The tiny actuator parts that are non steel have a tendency to want to float right out of the head and right down your sink drain! Other than that it will do the job with a little of your effort.

  155. Over the last few years, I have bought many nose hair trimmers from Amazon. Specifically, I have bought the [[ASIN:B0049LUI9O Panasonic ER-GN30-K Nose, Ear n Facial Hair Trimmer Wet/Dry with Vortex Cleaning System, Black]] twice and [[ASIN:B000W405SG Philips Norelco NT9110/60 NoseTrimmer 3300 (Packaging May Vary)]] twice. The only reason I have bought them so many times is because they keep failing on me and breaking--either they won't cut even after cleaning or they won't power on at all even with a new battery (a lot of people have problems with the ERGN30K specifically, just look at the more critical reviews on that product page that explains why it breaks down). It was getting quite annoying buying new ones every year--so I also tried the heavily lauded [[ASIN:B000EBFJXS Groom Mate Platinum XL Nose & Ear Hair Trimmer]] because it didn't rely on a battery and people say it would last a lifetime--but it HURT LIKE HELL when cutting.<br /><br />While I cannot say anything about its durability yet (just got it last week--will update when/if it fails), I can already say this is the best nose hair trimmer I have ever bought thus far--which is KIND OF SAD CONSIDERING EARLIEST REVIEWS OF THIS PRODUCT DATE BACK TO 2006! (aside: think of all the inventions/discoveries we made since 2006--and after 9 years no one made a better product to cut nose hair?!)<br /><br />The vacuum system TRULY works and makes a WORLD of difference--goodbye sneezing while cutting and blowing your nose 50 times to try to get all the little hairs out.<br /><br />It also just feels a lot more hefty and durable than the Panasonic ER-GN30-K. However, only time will tell if it will outlast the other nose hair trimmer bestsellers on Amazon. I promise to update when it fails--but if you want to make sure mine is still alive and kicking whenever you are buying, just comment on this review and I will update you.<br /><br />But for now, the extra 5 dollars over the other bestselling models is sooooo worth it.t.

  157. (Before I begin, I will say that I bought this solely for the intention of trimming the hair in my nostrils.) I was a bit skeptical at first because I never really used one of these things before, but after seeing the high ratings and feedback I decided I would go for the Panasonic ER430K. I am writing this review just 1 minute after using this thing and let me tell you, it not only got all the hair out of my nose (it is like a forest in there) but it sucked the hair out as it was trimming it, just like a vacuum; exactly like it advertised! I did not experience any kind of discomfort such as pulling or anything. I did however enjoy the sound of my nose hair getting trimmed off and sucked away as I moved this little trimmer around in my nostril. Cleaning was a breeze, because all the hair is vacuumed up there is no mess and the hair sits nicely inside the filter which can be easily removed and cleaned by running some water through it, same goes for the blades too. I am very happy with this purchase and I can't wait to use it again!
  158. Seeking to avoid the \\"Lon Cheney as the Wolfman!\\" look from vintage movie posters, I bought one of these a couple months back. So far, I'm pleased. It trims nose hairs and upper mustache hairs well (though I'll be honest, it tickles the bejesus out of my nose!), ear hairs, and I've even used it on a few errant eyebrow hairs that were getting out of hand. It comes apart easily for cleaning, and being able to put it under the faucet is a really nice feature. The only caveat that keeps it at 4 stars is that it sometimes takes 3-4 passes to get all the hairs you're afer. Some of this is due to learning how to hold it, and some is due to the cylindrical guard on the blade, which makes it a little tricky to get the hairs and the blades in contact. Still, it's better than cutting your nose open with an exposed blade, so I'm not complaining. Good trimmer, great cleanup.

It was okay for those baby hairs but at some point in the aging process they got out of hand and I needed a solution. I debated spending $20 such a specialized product but it was absolutely worth it.<br /><br />The product runs on a single AA battery, I'm using an Energizer Lithium battery for extended life. The unit is also larger than I expected, the size is required to support the vacuum motor and fan, but it's not too big, it fits comfortably in my hand. A cap is supplied to cover the end that spends the most time crammed into your nose. On said clip there is a small mirror in case you need to trim up when no mirror is available, an added bonus. The small black inconspicuous bag is also a nice touch. Now that I spent the money I sort of wished I would have spent a little more for a unit with a built-in light.

  247. Purchased this from The Art of Shaving 6 months ago. I ended up giving it away and purchased the Panasonic GNK30 which I am much happier with... I am not a person who posts many reviews, but in this case I wish I would have known a few things and/or purchased a different trimmer from the get go. For the record I am not an extremely hairy person but I do groom frequently. That being said my personal opinion: The vacuum feature doesn't add much function but would irritate my nostrils and cause me to sneeze which I disliked (never had this problem without the vacuum feature on past trimmers). This unit burns through batteries fairly quickly which can be annoying as when they start to die it doesn't cut as well and causes the dreaded tearing out of hair. For whatever reason it didn't seem to cut as well as my 10 year old Remington nose trimmer either right out of the box and cut quality seems to directly relate to battery strength ie cuts very well after a fresh battery, but the last few weeks of battery life before they die out is painful. It is not a terrible trimmer and may work well for others as it has great reviews, but my personal experience was not quite as great as others have had. Best of luck!

  256. I bought a Panasonic nose and ear hair trimmer some 6 years ago and was quite happy with it until it gave up its ghost. Upon ordering this new Panasonic ER430K ear and nose hair trimmer and using it for the first time, I have to agree with some of the other informed users: it's not doing its job! You really have to read the fine print on Panasonic's product description to learn that Panasonic changed the blade angle from 90 degrees to 60 degrees, presumably out of legal concerns because some idiots could sue Panasonic if they hurt themselves using the trimmer. The prior Panasonic devices, featuring a 90 degree blade/cutting angle were perfect for a close shave. This new, legally improved 60 degree arrangement does not cut/shave close enough and leaves 2 to 3 millimeter stubbles of hair in your nose and ears. No good. If I want to get rid of nose or ear hair, I want it gone, PERIOD, and not have stubbles remaining. If you're as perfectionist as I am, you will NOT want this \\"improved\\" Panasonic trimmer -- and, unfortunately, the way I understant it, this new blade/cutting angle applies to all Panasonic nose and ear hair trimmers. Amazon is amazing:) in its return policy -- and that's the way it should be. I got the full refund and am experimenting with other nose and ear hair trimmers. Actually, I just got a cheapo $9 Conair trimmer at Bed, Bath & Beyond, and it seems to be doing its job quite nicely. However, I will reserve my final verdict until another trim.

  261. I am blessed with hairy nostrils. It's a sign of wisdom, and virility. Okay, so it helps when I think about it that way. Anyhow, I've tried a number of trimmer models and brands, but find that the Panasonics have the sharpest and most comfortable blades. If the blades aren't sharp, the hairs are pulled out before they're cut, and that kinda hurts! The Panasonic trimmers I've tried are also very well made, are nice and small, and very easy to hold / move around.<br /><br />When my last trimmer became a little dull, I decided to replace it with a new Panasonic, and found the Panasonic ER430K on Amazon. It cost a little more than I had paid for this sort of item before, but based on my experiences with other Panasonic trimmers, I thought I'd go ahead and purchase it.<br /><br />My immediate impression when I opened the box was that this was another excellent, well-made trimmer. It's a little bit bulkier than I had expected, but that's not surprising since it has the vacuum feature, and it wasn't hard to get used to. It comes with a nice case, and cap, too.<br /><br />All in all, I'm completely satisfied with it, and I would recommend Panasonic ER430K to anyone considering a trimmer purchase.

  341. This trimmer worked better than I expected. No pain, no mess, just effortless trimming. I would only list two minor drawbacks. First, the trimmer has several pieces to remove when cleaning it out, and the pieces are delicate, so you have to be pretty careful. Second, I wasn't aware that this trimmer ran on a AA battery when I bought it, although I see it is listed in the product description, so be aware of that. I have used the trimmer several times and haven't had to replace the battery yet.
  342. I am impressed with the trimmer. The cost is justified. The only things that maybe I will say is, the nose clipping could be better.
  343. Not that I have a lot but keeping the nose hair from tickling my nose is always good.<br /><br />It works great, have a vacuum and easy to clean.

The mirror on the cap is a nice touch, but pretty small. It's hard to really see anything in it. The carrying case is pretty chintzy, but I don't anticipate using it. My biggest complaint is that if pressed upon the skin too hard or at the wrong angle, the blade inside of the nozzle quite easy butts up against and scrapes skin. As you can imagine, this isn't desirable given how sensitive the inside of the nose can be.<br /><br />Aside from that complaint the trimmer works well. Battery life is pretty good but not great. The trimmer is very easy to clean. Water can introduced into the trimmer while it's running without causing any problems. The top section disassembles for easy cleaning. The included carrying case is a nice addition but I feel that it's made of lint grabbing material so I haven't used it. If it were more difficult to accidentally come into contact with the spinning blade I would have given the trimmer another star. If the battery life were a little better I would have rated it five stars. Next time I need a trimmer I'll look elsewhere.

You have to be sure to peel any plastic from the mirror cap in order to obtain a clear reflection. You may think you have peeled it off but there is a second plastic film layer in addition to the packaging plastic film cover (if it still looks dull you may not have taken off the second plastic film layer). I have only had it for a few months but I am very happy with the product.

  426. The current crop of personal nose hair trimmers don't work as well as the old ones- it seems that the blades are now contained in a housing that increases safety, but in turn they are harder to use. I have tried several that don't work at all, in fact, but I thought I would give Panasonic one last try when I read good reviews of the 430K. This one actually does the job quite well when it comes to trimming nose hairs and the vacuum feature makes for easy cleanup. In terms of trimming ear hairs, I find that it doesn't work at all, due to the safety blade housing I mentioned earlier, but I have resigned myself to using tweezers for that task. While not as good as the older trimmers, this one is nice to use and easily the best of the bunch.

  456. After years of owning [[ASIN:B000063XHR Panasonic's ER112BC Nose Hair Trimmer]], it was time for something new: the old trimmer wasn't starting up reliably, requiring a firm smack to get it going.<br /><br />I can't say I had too many complaints about the old trimmer, but ended up with this ER430K model after reading the positive Amazon reviews and rationalizing it was worth spending a few bucks more. I'm glad I did.<br /><br />Compared with my old 112 model, the 430 cuts at a higher RPM, and doesn't get bogged down -- not that my nose hair is particularly bushy, but I could always detect the subtle changes in RPM while the old 112 model went about its business. Also, the old 112 either pulled some of my hairs or else lightly nicked my skin, while this 430 can be held or pressed at any odd angle without such an effect.<br /><br />The \\"vacuum\\" function of this 430 model -- well, I haven't completely figured it out, i.e. where the clippings disappear to and how much actual suction is occuring -- but I'll tell you that I don't breathe in any sneeze-inducing clippings like I did with my old 112 model. So whatever this vacuum is/isn't, its intended purpose works as intended.<br /><br />The cap mostly stays on when this rattles around my drawer, and the case is a nice touch for traveling.<br /><br />Overall, I can't understand why Panasonic markets so many nose hair trimmers in such a narrow price range, but ultimately it's their business to do so. But as a consumer, I can't see why somebody would settle on the the 112 model when for just a little more, they can own this ER430K, which is clearly superior.

It's all I could ask for. Prior to this, I used a fancy Norelco that didn't cut as closely or comfortably as this one, and, IIRC, cost about 50 bucks. After about 5 years, it just up and died. This is a better product at less than half the cost.

Maybe I was used to the slim and thinner design of its predecessors, but this trimmer will take some getting used to as it is a big boy. The only negative I could find is that it will actually trim VERY close and thoroughly, leaving almost a stubble in your nose that can be irritating for a couple days when you rub your nose. Sometimes he's plucking out pesky nose hairs. For decades my thorny nose hairs caused maddening irritation as they vibrated against my nasal passages. When the itching and sneezing got to be too much, out came the tweezers.<br /><br />I was afraid to use a trimmer for fear the device would get choked with \\"thorns\\" and yank them out by the root. Amazon makes it easy to return a shipment, however.<br /><br />For some reason Nads nose wax is not available from retailers. So far I'm happy with my \\"shredder,\\" and not disappointed that Nads didn't work out.

Soon, the cover kept falling off, then the cutters became dull and started to pinch little...and then, the switch stopped working. After reading reviews, I purchased the Panasonic. This is a huge improvement! The motor is quieter and revs more RPM's. The smaller head is makes it easier to navigate for precision. The blade cover snaps on more securely. Also, the unit stands up - which makes it easier to store in my medicine cabinet and grab hold of. The switch is also much better. Time will tell how well this product will work well, but it seems to be well made enough.

  867. My husband suffers from a spinal cord injury and has problems with dexterity. He has no problems with this product.
  868. First, this is the fourth nose trimmer of this type I have owned. None of them pulled my nose hairs, probably because I used them properly. It takes about ten minutes of use to get rid of all hairs. First you glide it on the interior surface of each nostril pushing it up and down and rotating it about ten degrees nine times. Then you use your index finger to press the tip of your nose towards your face. This changes the shape of your nostrils. You then angle the device about 20 degrees with respect to the vertical and do the above mentioned ritual. Then angel the trimmer 45 degrees to the vertical and to it all again. Then you check the results. Insert your thumb in each nostril and put your index finger on the outside of the nose. Press them together and pull them towards the opening. This will reveal hairs that are still too long. If you have not yet died of boredom, repeat all of the above ritual but just in the are of the newly discovered long hairs.
  869. I never had a need for this type of trimmer in the past. But that was the past because now it has become a must have. Does a great job and I'm glad I made the purchase. I would definitely select the Panasonic again.

The reason why I hate it was quite unexpected. . . . .and no one who wrote reviews of the product said anything about this. . . . The reason is. . . . After you cut your nose hairs. . . then the \\"ends\\" (stubble) is sharp. . . Then when you go to blow your nose, for example, and you're pressing against your nose, the \\"stubble\\" goes into the opposite side . . . and it's \\"uncomfortable\\". It's not quite as bad as pins sticking in. . . but . . .it's certainly \\"uncomfortable\\". I've not trimmed for a few weeks now, and it's gotten better. Unless I really feel that trimming is necessary. . . then I'm not going to do it any longer. Certainly it makes sense for those people who have such issues. . . .but. .. at least for now. . . I'm really not one of those people. But I'm glad to have this item, should I get a \\"wild hair\\".

  1024. Let's face it. Nose hair is not attractive on anyone. If you can't keep it trimmed, what can you do? This trimmer is a must-have - even if you have those other nose trimmers or even the popular 'bikini' trimmer shown on TV. Those trimmers are good for trimming the circumference of the nose (the skin portion in a circular motion). However, nose hair is tricky and likes to grow in the worst of places. While you got the hairs on the edge of the nose, you can still be growing long hair deep inside the nose. That is where the Panasonic Vacuum Nose Trimmer comes in!<br /><br />Pros:<br />-Does what traditional personal trimmers can't do<br />-Gets the hair deep back in the nose at the source<br />-Vacuum actually does suck out those hairs<br />-Device is easy to take apart to remove old hairs and clean<br /><br />Cons:<br />-Let's get serious. That so-called mirror that is attached to the handle of this trimmer is just a reflective sticker. You'd be better off looking at your reflection in a pool of motor oil.

  1403. When I purchased this product, the main complaint was that quite a few people had the same issue - that it stopped working soon after purchase.   1476. Comfortable to use and plainly it gets the job done
  1477. I received the trimmer today. It came in an easy cardboard container to open, and what you get is the trimmer, and a black felt bag for I guess if you travel, or if you choose to store it in the bag when at home. You also need to have a AA battery to insert. In order to insert the battery, the instructions says to turn counterclockwise and match the line A with B, and pull to open. Course, with me being literal, I tried to find the letter A and B to match it up but couldn't. There is no A or B. A is a not so noticeable line on the bottom &#34;firm&#34; part of the trimmer. It's on the little &#34;spoke&#34; next to the screw (but you don't unscrew it). B is the battery cap that has the Model Number, and on the cap, is an arrow that points to a &#34;dot&#34;. The &#34;dot&#34; is B, so you line up the DOT with the line on the spoke, and then you pull. Doing a few times you don't even need to look. And it is hard to see so make sure you have some light and/reading glasses (if you need it) but again, once you do it one time, it's so easy to remove and replace the battery.<br /><br />Also, reading the instructions, to perform maintenance on it, you need to remove 5 separate things (including the cover) sot hat you can clean the outer blade and inner blade, and filter. The last item is the housing for the outer blade. Besides blowing to remove the hair, it says to use a soft tissue and gently wipe the blades and it says it can be washed in water. Course I don't know if its totally waterproof so I would take out the battery just in case if you were to go that route. It also says if used once a week, for 1 min, the blade should last 3 years.<br /><br />If you're like me, I was a little nervous about taking each item apart to clean as I think I might not be able to put them together again. I tried couple of times and again, after a while, it should be easy to maintain. The instructions are pretty clear on how the separate pieces.<br /><br />So anyways, the first time I used it to remove the nose hair, I gotta say, it sure tickled. Not sure if I will ever get use to the feeling vs using scissors, but like anything, eventually you'll get use to it....maybe LOL It seems to be made good quality wise so if anything changes, I'll do an update.

I found this out the hard way. I suppose you don't need to trim so far in anyways, but feeling how well the thing cut, I couldn't resist trying.<br /><br />Cleanup is easy with water, and as with all electronics, water resistant or not, I always allow it to air dry disassembled.<br /><br />The cap is a little annoying with that arm- it's not like it could clip to the pocket, so the arm is a mystery to me. You do have to fuss with it a little when you first assemble it and then every time you need to empty the little chamber of its hairy contents, but you don't have to empty it very often, and it's only a minute or two at most to accomplish the process. My other small complaint is that it is noisier than my last ear-and-nose trimmer, but that is probably because it has a more powerful motor. The first battery I put in it a few months ago is still going strong, so it's not a battery drainer like some little gadgets. It doesn't look like it could get all of an ear hair, but there is nothing to see after I've &#34;mowed it&#34; with this device, and that's the bottom line. This would make a great little gift for anyone who has the problem of unwanted ear and nose hairs. Update 11/15/16: Well, it was great while it lasted, but it should have lasted a lot longer. The problem is in the battery chamber. The batteries don't stay &#34;pressed together&#34; enough most of the time for it to function. Sometimes I can shake the thing and get it to work for a short while, but lately even that has not been doing the trick. (Yes, I've replaced the batteries; it has nothing to do with the batteries running down.) So my five-star review has devolved into a two-star review and I am in the market for another trimmer. :-(

  1557. When I bought this, my husband (this is his account) was like, &#34;Why the hell did you buy that?!&#34;<br />Well, because I absolutely hate plucking nose hairs... who doesn't right?<br /><br />He's one of those dudes that will just reach in there and rip a pinchful right out!<br /><br />Well, after I used it the first time and explained to him that it sucks away any loose hairs, he FINALLY gave it a shot... he totally digs it, too.   1558. I never thought I'd actually be excited to write a review for a nose and ear trimmer! But I am, because this little gadget works! I have had some very expensive personal groomers, and I was never happy with the nose and ear trimming functions--they just did not do the job. I would often have to use blunt scissors in addition to the trimmer. This little trimmer works perfectly--your nostrils and your ears will be clean! And yes, it does vacuum the cut hairs away. Another reviewer had wondered, where does the hair go? Well, it goes into the blade chamber itself, which you will see when you clean the blades (you must clean the blade-chamber after every use). The blades are delicate and need to be cleaned carefully--I advise using a brush of some sort or a cotton swab. The instructions say, that with normal use, the blades will wear out in about three years. I like this product so much, I thought of buying another just to keep as a spare! (I checked, you can't buy replacement blades, the product is not built that way). One slight drawback--it works on batteries, you can't plug it in. What I do is, keep the batteries out of the chamber when not in use, that way you're not draining the batteries while the trimmer sits idle--the batteries go in so easily, that it is not a big deal to take them out and put them back in. (I use the trimmer once every two weeks or so).
